facts.text: Appellants carried on business in partnership as Ishwarsing Dhiansingh, owners of two motor trucks: No. AWB 230 (V-8 Ford 1938 Model) and No. AWB 253 (Oldsmobile Model 1938).
On May 4, 1942, appellants entered into agreement hiring out trucks to respondent for imparting tuition to military personnel at Rs. 17 per day per truck, terminable on one month's notice.
Truck No. AWB 230 handed over to respondent on April 29, 1942; truck No. AWB 253 on May 4, 1942.
Respondent used AWB 230 from April 29, 1942 to July 31, 1942, except June 4-9, 1942; AWB 253 from May 4, 1942 to July 31, 1942, except June 1-9, 1942.
On June 29, 1942, respondent gave notice terminating agreement effective August 1, 1942, asked appellants to remove trucks.

On August 1, 1942, appellant No. 1 attended Officer Commanding 4 T.T. Centre, Kamptee at 9 a.m. to remove trucks, but not delivered by transport in-charge; appellant No. 1 wrote letter same date to S.S.O., Kamptee.
Respondent did not return trucks or pay hire charges; claimed hire paid and trucks delivered to Surjan Singh, alleged partner of appellants.
Appellants denied Surjan Singh was partner entitled to receive payment/delivery.

On August 4, 1942, appellants gave notice u/s 80 CPC claiming: (i) hire up to July 31, 1942 at Rs.17/day +6% interest; (ii) damages Rs.17/day/truck from Aug 1, 1942 till delivery; (iii) return trucks or Rs.3,500 value.
Suit filed January 8, 1943 vs respondent and Surjan Singh for above reliefs + future damages from suit date to delivery + costs.

Plaint: cause of action failure to pay hire and non-delivery due to wrongful delivery to Surjan Singh; entitled to return or value at decree date; reserved right to claim excess value due to price rise by additional court fee.

Trial Court (Third Additional District Judge, Nagpur, July 7, 1944): Held respondent not justified in paying/delivering to Surjan Singh; awarded Rs.2,380 hire + interest @6% from Aug 1, 1942 to Jan 7, 1943; Rs.3,500 value +6% interest as damages; no mesne profits; total Rs.6,032-4-0 + costs vs both defendants.

Appeal to Nagpur High Court (First Appeal No. 27 of 1954 from judgment April 7, 1948): Appellants claimed Rs.11,985 + highest market value; valued appeal at Rs.5,953, paid court fee; later paid additional Rs.1,279-11-0 on Rs.16,626.

High Court (Division Bench, April 1, 1948 judgment?): Disallowed higher truck value (claimed only Rs.3,500 in s.80 notice); for damages, compensated till July 7, 1944 at Rs.17/day but limited enhancement to Rs.5,953 (original appeal claim); total enhanced by Rs.5,953 (incl. Rs.5,477 additional compensation).
Certificate u/s 110 CPC granted; appeal to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Rights and remedies of bailor when bailee fails to deliver goods: whether action lies in wrongful conversion (trover) or wrongful detention (detinue), and bailee's ability to insist on conversion despite election.
Measure of value of goods in detinue: at date of tort/breach or at date of judgment/decree.
Damages for wrongful detention: quantum, whether hire rate for reasonable use period, or nominal/interest.
Effect of s.80 CPC notice claiming Rs.3,500 value: bars claim for appreciated value at decree date.

petitioner_arguments.text: Suit for wrongful detention (detinue); entitled to return of trucks or value at date of decree (Rs.7,000 each, total Rs.14,000).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Action in detinue; value at judgment date

petitioner_arguments.text: In addition, damages for wrongful detention at Rs.17 per day per truck from August 1, 1942 till July 7, 1944 (trial decree date).

respondent_arguments.text: At worst, wrongful conversion from August 1, 1942; entitled only to value at conversion date + 6% interest.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Action in trover; value at tort date

respondent_arguments.text: Even if detention, not more than value at trial decree date + nominal damages till July 7, 1944; High Court award sufficient, appeal to be dismissed.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Anderson v. Passman (nominal damages unless special)

court_reasoning.text: Bailor entitled to elect detinue even after bailee's conversion/delivery to third party; bailee cannot take advantage of own wrong (Reeve v. Palmer, Wilkinson v. Verity).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Plaintiff's election governs; no delay to speculate on market.

court_reasoning.text: In detinue, value assessed at judgment date, not tort date; continuing wrong till delivery or decree.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinction from conversion where tort complete at misdelivery.

court_reasoning.text: s.80 notice complied with common sense reading; claimed return or then-value Rs.3,500; suit reserves appreciation claim.
Evidence shows value appreciated to Rs.7,000 by judgment; Trial/High Court erred.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rs.3,500 was Aug 1942 value; doubled by 1944.

court_reasoning.text: Damages for detention: reasonable hire rate (Rs.17/day/truck) for period trucks would have been in commission (~1 year, 365 days); total Rs.12,410; High Court limited wrongly to original claim.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Analogy to land detention; appellants' hiring business.

holdings.text: Bailor may elect detinue despite prior conversion by bailee; bailee cannot object.
In detinue, alternative value of goods at date of judgment/decree.
Damages for wrongful detention: reasonable hiring rate for expected use period, not limited by court fee or nominal.

precedents_cited.relevance: Bailee cannot set up own wrongful delivery as answer to detinue.
Bailor elects remedy; bailee cannot better position by own wrong.
In detinue, value at judgment date even if converted; same principle regardless of reason for non-return.
Measure of damages same in conversion/detinue if possession wrongful; consider delay.
Evolution of modern actions; conversion requires unequivocal ownership act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Strand Electric Engineering Co. Ltd. v. [implied defendant]
precedents_cited.relevance: Damages for detention: reasonable hire even if owner no loss.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bhagchand Dagadusa v. Secretary of State
precedents_cited.relevance: Strict compliance s.80 but with common sense.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal; notice before suit against government.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; in addition to High Court enhanced decree: Rs.3,500 appreciated value of trucks +6% interest from July 7, 1944; additional Rs.6,457 damages for detention; additional proportionate costs in trial/High Court + SC costs; subject to additional court fee.
outcome.relief_granted: Rs.3,500 value + interest; Rs.6,457 additional damages; costs.
outcome.costs: Additional proportionate costs in lower courts + costs of appeal.

key_quotes.text: "It is the option of the plaintiff to pursue either remedy against the bailee just as it suits him having regard to all the circumstances of the case and the bailee cannot be heard to say anything to the contrary for the simple reason that he cannot take advantage of his own wrong."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on bailor's election of remedy.

key_quotes.text: "In detinue, the value of the goods to be paid by the defendants to the plaintiff in the event of the defendants failing to return the goods to the plaintiff must be assessed as at the date of the verdict or judgment."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Adopts Rosenthal for value assessment date.

key_quotes.text: "A wrongdoer who keeps the owner out of his land must pay a fair rental value for it, even though the owner would not have been able to use it himself... I see no reason why the same principle should not apply to detention of goods."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Basis for hire-rate damages in detention.
